Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Ej.606 - Northern Andean Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest CR (EN -- CR)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Ej.606 - Northern Andean Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest CR (EN -- CR)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.3.Ej.606 - Northern Andean Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.3.Ej Tropical Andean Montane Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.
Assessment-Target.AT-name: 1.A.3.Ej.606 - Northern Andean Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques altos (15-25 m), con multiples estratos. Tienen una gran biomasa de epifitas, los bosques del cinturon inferior son mas altos y pueden presetar una alta frecuencia de palmeras. Los bosques en el cinturon superior son mas bajos y tienen una alta porcion de arboles con hojas esclerofilas. La composicion a nivel de especies y dominancia varian a lo largo de su distribucion altitudinal y latitudinal

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.A.3.Ej.606 - Northern Andean Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverdes montano humedo Se encuentran en todas las vertientes de las montañas andinas de Venezuela, Colombia y Ecuador, tambíen en la punta mas septentrional de los Andes occidentales de la cordillera de Perú. Entre los 2200 y 3800 msnm
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.3.Ej.606 - Northern Andean Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CR was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os EN -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of EN -- CR.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.A.3.Ej.610 - Central Andean (Yungas) Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverdes montano humedo. 2. Bsq. Bajo y 3. Bsq semi-esclerofilo Se encuentra en la vertiente oriental de los Andes de Perú y Bolivia. En general estan entre los 2200-3500 msnm. Estos 3 tipos de bosques tambien se encuentran entre los 3000-4500 msnm en la sierra andina escarpada, comunmente en los circos glaciares.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.3.Ej.610 - Central Andean (Yungas) Montane & Upper Montane Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os VU -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- EN.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Ej.611 - Central Andean (Yungas) Lower Montane Humid Forest NT (LC -- VU)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Ej.611 - Central Andean (Yungas) Lower Montane Humid Forest NT (LC -- VU)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.3.Ej.611 - Central Andean (Yungas) Lower Montane Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.3.Ej Tropical Andean Montane Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.
Assessment-Target.AT-name: 1.A.3.Ej.611 - Central Andean (Yungas) Lower Montane Humid Forest

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Clima humedo a hiper-humedo Suelos humico, profundos y bien drenados.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Existen dos variantes: 1. Zonas dominadas por la palma Dictyocaryum lamarckianum son menos diversas. 2. Zona donde encontramos bosque es extremadamente diversa.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.A.3.Ej.611 - Central Andean (Yungas) Lower Montane Humid Forest

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq Montano humedo Se presentan entre los 1200-1400 msnm y los 1700-2000 msnm. Se encuentran en laderas superiores o crestas de montañas sub-andinas expuestas a la lluvia y niebla(Fisionomia palmeral). Tambíen los encontramos en pendientes menos pronunciadas y suelos mas profundos (fisionomia forestal).

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criterion and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os LC -- VU.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Ej.614 - Moist Puna Humid Forest NE'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Ej.614 - Moist Puna Humid Forest NE'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.3.Ej.614 - Moist Puna Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.3.Ej Tropical Andean Montane Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques con alturas entre los 3-10 m, con un dosel discontinuo formado por Polylepis y otros generos de arboles y arbustos. Al tener un dosel abierto permite el desaroolo de un estrato inferior herbaceo, incluyendo los helechos.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Montano humedo se distribuye en los Andes donde se presenta el ecotono con praderas altoandinas
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: 'Chilean Winter Rainfall and Valdivian Forests' Hotspot

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
